title: 112_s3214
content: The "Today's Entrepreneurs are America's Mentors Act" or the "TEAM Act" defines terms related to small business concerns and establishes an Office of Entrepreneurial Education within the Small Business Administration. The "TEAM Act" establishes the Office of Entrepreneurial Education within the Small Business Administration to provide innovative entrepreneurial information, education, and resources for prospective entrepreneurs and small business concerns. The Director of the Office manages online courses, publications, and resources, as well as youth entrepreneurship programs. The Office of Entrepreneurial Education within the Small Business Administration manages youth entrepreneurship programs, coordinates with private sector partners for financial literacy education, and provides assistance to individuals interested in entrepreneurship. The Office of Entrepreneurial Education within the Small Business Administration oversees youth entrepreneurship programs and collaborates with private sector partners for financial literacy education. The National Primary and Secondary School Entrepreneurial Education Program aims to provide grants to nonprofit organizations for technical assistance in developing curricula and mentoring programs for promoting entrepreneurship in schools. The Small Business Administration's Office of Entrepreneurial Education collaborates with private sector partners to provide grants to nonprofit organizations for developing curricula and mentoring programs to promote entrepreneurship in schools. Nonprofit organizations applying for grants must describe project goals, list partners, and submit necessary information. Within a year of receiving a grant, organizations must report on individuals assisted, jobs created or saved, and other grant usage details. The Office of Entrepreneurial Education provides grants to nonprofit organizations for entrepreneurial education programs. Organizations must report on individuals assisted, jobs created or saved, and grant usage details. Additionally, a report on best practices of entrepreneurial education programs in the US is required within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The Committee on Small Business of the House of Representatives will submit a report on best practices of entrepreneurial education and training programs in the US, including descriptions of exemplary programs at national, regional, state, and local levels, as well as a summary of programs by the Federal Government, state and local governments, and nonprofit organizations and private sector groups. The Master of Business Administration Scholarship Pilot Program is established. The Administrator may award up to 100 scholarships of $1,500 each to MBA students on a competitive basis. Recipients must provide free assistance to small businesses for 1-2 weeks. At least 50% of recipients must be students from institutions with limited entrepreneurship opportunities. The Administrator awards scholarships to MBA students for providing free assistance to small businesses. Recipients must support various entrepreneurial projects and have a mentor. Recipients and businesses must provide information on the assistance provided. The Administrator awards scholarships to MBA students for assisting small businesses. Recipients must provide information on the assistance given and employment status for 3 years after graduation. Failure to comply results in the scholarship being treated as a loan. $200,000 is authorized for the Administrator annually. The Administrator may award scholarships to MBA students for assisting small businesses, with $200,000 authorized annually. Scholarships cannot be awarded after September 30, 2015. SEC. 5. REGIONAL ENTREPRENEURIAL COMPETITIONS. The Administrator will establish a program for regional competitions and a national conference to address challenges through entrepreneurial research and business planning. Regional offices will identify issues, sponsor competitions for small businesses, and collaborate with various organizations to promote the competition and request proposals. The Administrator will organize a national conference for presenting selected research and business plans from regional competitions. 11 employees will be designated for a panel to review the plans. The Administrator will designate 11 employees to serve on a panel that selects the best research and business plans from regional competitions. Each selected plan will receive a $50,000 grant. The Administrator will award a $50,000 grant to selected plans from regional competitions. Recipients must submit a report on grant usage within a year. $750,000 is authorized for the Administrator to carry out this section. SEC. 6. STUDY ON ENTREPRENEURIAL DEFERMENT OF STUDENT LOANS. The Administrator, in consultation with the Secretary of Education, must submit a report to Congress within 180 days with recommendations for legislation to forgive and defer student loans to support youth entrepreneurship and business formation.
